availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

lg.l: Free, fresh, savage,

Fluent, luxuiriant, self-content, fond
of persons and places,

Fond of fish-shape Paumanok where
I was born, fond of the sea,
large-begotten,

Boy of the Mannahatta, Boy of
the south savannas,

Full-breath'd on Cuban, Californian,
Arizonian air,

Resounding Niagara, resounding
Mississippi,

Rude in my home in Kanuck
woods,

A prairie-man, a mountain-man,
may drink water,

Aware of the buffalo, the peace- Stars, rain, snow, grass, wind, trees, may amaze, may love,
herds, the bull strong-breasted
and hairy,

Aware of the mocking-bird of the
wilds at daybreak,

Solitary, singing in the west, I
strike up
the songs of
for
a
new world.—

I will makes the
poems
songs
of passions,
(43) to give them their way.—
And your
poems
songs
offenders,
for I scan you with kindred
eyes, and carry you with
me the same as any;

And I will make the true
(44) poem of riches, namely, to
earn for the body and the
mind what adheres and goes
forward, and is not dropt by
death,
I am the child of Democracy,

I advance from the people
en-masse, in their own
spirit,

I chant a strong and haughty
chant for you, my mother.

I will be the preparer of what is
to come.—
I will take exciption to nothing,
I will take exception to nothing

I will
sing
trail
the whole geography
of the
earth,
New World,
globe,
and salute
courteously every city large
and small.
This then is life,

This
Here
is what has risen on the
earth after so many throes
and convulsions.
How curious! How real!

Under-foot, the divine soil
!
,
—Over-
head the sun
!
.
—

Take my Leaves America!
Yield
Make
their roots,
places to for—everywhere for them them, every-where,
for they are your offspring,
O my native Earth Soil and Sun

O native spoil and native Daughters
perpetuate them!
O inland and seaboard perpetuate them!

Waft them O winds! Buoy
them,
O waters
liquid lakes
!

Surround them, east and west,
for they would surround you—
and north and south, for they
would you,

And you precedents connect lovingly
with them, for they
are to
would
connect lovingly with you.

And employments! I will make
a song that with you is
heroism upon land and
sea—And I will report all
heroism from an American
point of view,

And sexual organs and acts! do
you concentrate in me—for
I am determined to tell
you with courageous clear
voice, to prove you illustrious.
I will make the song of companionship,

I will show
love to
whatonly above can
compact
Democracy,
These States,

I believe the main purport
of
These States
America
is to found
a new
type
ideal
of manly
friendship, more ardent,
more general,

I will thereforelet appear these
burning
flames
fires
of adhesive-
ness that were threatening to
consume me,

I will lift what has too
long kept down those
smouldering
flames
fires
—I will
now expose them, and use them.

I will make the new evangelical
poem of lovers and comrades,

(For who but I should understand
love, with all its sorrow
and joy?

And who but I should be
the poet of comrades?)
I returned to old times,

I sat, a child, a listener,
among
at the feet of
the great masters,

Now, if it be eligible let
the great masters themselves return
and listen to me.—
This exstasy touching and thrilling me,

This contact daily and hourly that will
not release me,

How—how effective at last
they are
it all has become
upon
me!

Not he whom I love, kissing me so long
with his daily kiss, has winded and
twisted around me that which holds
me to him forever,

Any more than I am become welded
to the heavens, to the
unseen
spiritual
world, and to the identities of
the Gods, my unseen lovers, after what
they have done to me.—
Democracy!

FOr you a throat is now inflating itself
and is joyfully singing.—for your and
Ma femme!
Our offspring shall be provided for,

None could come to do what was
wanted till I have come,

For you, and something beyond you, I will sned
forth my strong and haughty
ballads
chants
,
—
different from those of all the rest
of the earth.—
in the morning light,

When I wandered alone over the
beach, and undressing, bathed, laughing
with the waters, and saw the
sun rise,

And I will effuse egotism, and
show egotism underlying all—
and I will be the
b
B
ard of
p
P
er-
sonality,

And I will show of male and
female that either is but
the equal of the other,

And I will show that there is no
imperfection in male or
female, or in the earth, or
in the present, and can be
none in the future,

And I will show that whatever
happens to anybody it may
be turned to beautiful results—
and that nothing can happen
more beautiful than death

And I will thread a thread
through my poems that no
one thing in the universe is
inferior to another thing—
and that all the things of
the universe are perfect mira-
cles, each as profound
invariable
as any;

And I will not make poems
with reference to parts,
but I will make Leaves,
poems, poemets, songs, says,
thoughts, with reference to
the ensemble,
of the world,
universe,

And I will not sing with refer-
ence to a day, but with
reference to all days,

And I will not make a poem,
nor the least part of a
poem, but has reference
to the soul,

Because, having looked
upon
at
the
objects of the universe, I find
there is no one, nor any
particle of one, but has
reference to the soul.
Was somebody asking to see the soul?

See! Your own shape and counte-
nance, persons,
materials,
substances,
beasts, the trees, the birds,
the running rivers, the rocks
and sands.—

Mannahatta—boy of
the prairies, ?Boy of the something sav

Looking
friendlily
and longing
northwardwith
southward,
to live there and never depart— —
looking toward Niagara,—and beyond through Kanada, with equal love,

Resounding the Alleghanes,
re-
sounding the Mississippi,—
vocal, —natural,—spontaneous,

I, singing in the West, strike
up for The States.

Victory
Vista,
Victory
union, faith, democracy,
prudence, the soul, space,
time, the present and future
lands, yourself, the mysteries, kosmos,
invisible riches, and the modern reports.—
States!
you do not need maternity only,

you do not need to be born and
matured only,

There is a subtler inlfuence still
to go with your conformation.

As(38)I have walked my walk through the rows of the
orchard-trees, I
saw
have seen
where the
she-bird faithfully sat on her
nest, hatching her brood,

I(39)
saw
have seen
the he-bird, also—I heard him
where he sat by himself every day near
by
at hand
inflating his throat and joyfully
singing,

And 40 I have perceived that what he really sang
for must be something beyond the
she-bird.—

lg.head: II IV.
lg.l:
When I heard at the close of
the day how I had been
praised in the Capitol, still
it was not a happy
day
night
for me that followed,

And else, when I caroused—Or
when my plans were accomplished—
it was well enough—Still I
was not happy;

But
that day
that day
when I rose at dawn
from the bed of perfect health,
electric, inhaling sweet breath,

When I saw the full moon in the
west frow pale and disappear
The red aborigines!

Leaving natural breaths,
sounds of rain and wind,
calls as of birds and ani-
mals in the woods, syl-
labled to us for names,

O
c
k
onee,
C
K
oosa, Ottawa, Monon-
gahela, Sauk, Walla-Walla,
Natchez, Chattahoochee,
Anahua
Paumanok,
Walla-Walla,
Kaqueta, Orinoko

Wabash Miami, Alleghany, Connecti-
cut, Saginaw, Mannahatta,
Adiron-
dack, Chippewa, Oshkosh, Chip-
pewa, Alabama,

Leaving such to The States, they
melt, they depart, leaving
charging the water and
the land with names.—
No dainty dolce affectuoso I, now arrived,

I
have arrived
have arrived
step forth,
have
arrived
I have arrived—i Stop on my journey for a moment I on my journey, I pause,
gray, bearded, sun-
burnt, gray forbidding, to be wrestled
with as I pass for the solif prizes of the
universe,

For such I afford whoever can per-
severe to win them.—

On my way a moment I
pause,

Here for you! And here for
America!

Still the Present I raise
aloft—Still the Future,
of
T
ese States I harbinge
glad and sublime,

And for the Past I pronounce
what the air hold of
the red aborigines.—

I will make a song for These
States that no one State
shall
may
may
it must under any circumstances
to be subjected to another State,

And i will make a song that
there shall be faith and
comity by day and by night
between all The States, and
between any two of them,

And i will make a song of the
organic compacts of The
States—and a
fierce
shrill
song
of curses on him who would
dissever the union of The States,

And I will make a song for
the ears of the President, full
of weapons with menacing
points—and behind the weapons
the
countless
dissatisfied faces.—of people.
I am all-credulous,
I am the child of the commonalty,

I advance from the people en-masse in
their own spirit,
Here is what sings unrestricted faith
Here myself I give,

Here is my blood—Here are my pulses and
breaths,

My inward joys are here, and my sorrows
are all here.

From
In
what I compass here I reject
nothing,
accept all, what others scorn,
I make the dark poems of sin,

I do not
condemn
ignore
what is called evil—
I commemorate it also,

I am myself just as much evil
as good.—

l.del: will duly bind bring them to

lg.l:
I will duly place the canticles of it
here
of it, fit for These States,

I understand perfectly well that for
a man or nation is little or nothing without
Religion.—
I distinctly acknowledge Religion,

I understand perfectly well that Religion is the
vital
greatest
part of a man or a or nation
—and that no man or nation
can possibly be great without
it,
And I w

I know my poems were nothing without
it,

I am to make its canticles here—I
will make

All hold spiritual joys, and af-
terward loosens them.

How can
that real body ever
that which is really you,
die
and be buried?

Of
your real body and each
that which is really you, and
man's or woman's real body,
of any part of you,
item for item, it will elude
the hands of the corpse-cleaners,
and pass to fitting spheres,
carrying what has accrued to
it from the moment of birth
to the moment of death.

Not the types set up by the
printer return their impression,
the meaning, the main concern,
any more than a man's sub-
stance and life, or a woman's
substance and life, return in
the body and the soul indif-
ferently before death and
after death.—

Whoever you are! how superb and
how divine is your body, or
any part of it!

Whoever you are! to your endless
announcements!

Daughter of the lands, did you wait
for your poet?

Did you wait for one with a
flowing mouth and determined indicative
hand?

Toward the female of The States, and
toward the male of The States,

Toward the President, the Congress,
the diverse Governors, the
new Judiciary,

Live and severe words—Words to
the lands.—

O
t
T
he Lands!

Interlinked lands!
Hilarious lands!
Land of the common
people!
Food-yielding lands!

Lands ofcoal and iron! Land fo gold! Land
of cotton, sugar, rice!

Performed
Odorous
and sunny land! Floridian,
Alabamian, Texan land! Cu-
banese land!

Land of the Mississippi the spinal
river, the Mississippi! Land of the Alleghanies! Ohio's land!

land of wheat, beef, pork! Land
of wool and hemp! land
of the potato, the apple,
and the grape!

Land of the pastoral plains, the
grass-fields of the world!
Land of those sweet-aired
interminable plateaus! Land
there of the herd, the garden,
the healthy house of adobe!
land there of rapt thought,
and of the realization of the stars!
Land of simple, untamed, holy lives!

Ohio's land! Kanadian lands!
Lands
Lands where the north-west
Columbia winds, and where
the south-west Colorado winds!

Land of the Chesapeake! Land of
the Delaware!

Full-draped land, tied at the
breast with the belt stringing
the oval lakes!

Land of the future! Land of
the ceaseless right of rebellion!

Land of the Old Thirteen! And of
all since! And of all to come!
Lands of many oceans! Land of sierras and peaks!

Land of of boatsmen and sailors!
Fisherman's land!

Inextricable lands! The clutched
together! The passionate
lovers!

The side by side! The elder and
younger brothers! The boney-
limbed!

The great women's land! The
feminine! The experienced
sisters, and the inexperienced
sisters!

Far-breathed land! The
a
A
rti
c
-braced!
Mexican-breezed! The diverse! The compact!
The
The
Pennsylvanian! The
Tennesseean! The double
Carolinian!

All and each well-loved by me!
my intrepid nations! O I
cannot be discharged from you!

O death! O for all that, I am
yet of you, unseen, this
hour, with irrepressible love,

Walking
the Mannahatta,
New England,
a friend,
a traveler,

Spalshing my naked feet in the
edge of the summer ripples on
Paumanok's sands,

Crossing the prairies—dwelling
again in Chicago—dwelling
in many towns,

Observing shows, births, improvements,
structures, arts,

Listening to the orators and oratresses
in the public halls,

In and of
Of and through
The States as during life—
each man and woman my
neighbor,

The Louisianian, the Georgian, as
near to me, and I as near
to him and her,

The Kentuckian, Mississippian, Arkan-
sian, Missourian—the
workman
workwoman
of and
workwoman
workman
of Iowa,
Illinois, Indiana, Michigan,
Wisconsin, Minnesota, Kansas,
Nebraska, Utah, Dacotah! yet with
me, and I yet with any of them,

Yet in California or in Oregon, —yet in Arizonia
—yet
Yet upon the plains west of the
spinal river—yet in my
house of adobie,

Yet returning eastward,—yet in
Virginia,—yet in the Sea-Side
State, or in Maryland,

Yet
the
a
northern child—Yet Kanadian,
cheerily braving the winter—the snow
and ice welcome to me.

Yet the true son either of Maine,
or of the Granite State, or of
Vermont, Massachusetts, Connect-
icut, or of the Narraganset Bay
State, or of the Empire State,

Yet sailing forth to
other
shores,
to annex the same—Yet wel-
coming every new
equal,
mate,

Hereby applying these Leaves to the
new ones, from the hour
they unite with the old ones,

Coming among the new ones
myself to be their companion—
coming
directly
personally
to you now,

Enjoining you to acts, characters,
spectacles with me.

With me, with firm holding, yet
haste, haste on!
For your life, as I among adhere to me,
O only can unloose you and toughen you,

I may have to be persuaded many times
before I consent to give myself to you,—
but what of that?
Must not Nature be persuaded many times?

Here are the proofs and accumulations, lands that have ar-
Here are the
lands
days
lands
that female and male,
rived,

Here are is the
last descandants
heirship and heiresship
of the
world
,
.
—Here the flame of materials,

Here is Spirituality, the translatress,
the openly-avowed, the
ever-tending the finale of
visible forms, ¶The satisfier—after due long-waiting, now advancing,

Yes, here comes the mistress, the
soul.
The Soul!

Forever and forever—longer than
soil is brown and solid—
longer than water ebbs and
flows.—

I will make the poems of materials and
forms,
for I think they are to be
the most spiritual poems,

And I will make the poems of
my body and of mortality,
for I think I shall then
supply myself with the poems
of my soul and of immortality.—

I
remember ancient things,
do not forgetdiscredit old times

I
have listened to the past,
returned, to—
—I have
sat among
heard
studied
retraced
the great masters,
and listened to them,

Now if it be eligible let them
return with the rest and
listen to
study
me.
Dead poets philosophers and priests,

Captains, mothers,
M
artyrs, artists,
inventors, language-
makers
shapers
,
governments long since,

Nations once powerful, now reduced,
withdrawn, or desolate,

I
dare
dare
not proceed till I respect-
fully
turn my eyes upon
credit
what you have left,

I own how admirable, how in-
credible it is—I think none
can ever deserve more than
it deserves—I regard it
fixedly a long while,

Then I take my place for good,
on my own ground,
in my own days,
with
my own race.—today.— my own day. here and
Ships, men, elements, breeds,

Settlements, youthful, plentiful,
turbulent, quick and
audacious,

Elements, breeds, turbulent, quick auda-
cious,

A world primal again—Vistas
—of glory,
without end,
incessant and branching,

A new race, dominating all
previous ones, and grander
far,

New politics—New literatures
and religions—New inventions
and arts.—

These! These, my
ni
vo
ice an-
nouncing—I will sleep
no more but arise,

You oceans that have been
calm within me! how
I feel you, fathomless,
stirring, preparing unprecedented
waves and storms.—

For See!
steamships
steamers
steaming through my
poems ,!

See in my poems immigrants con-
tinually coming and landing,

See in arriere, the wigwam, the
war-scalp, the stone hatchet,
the trail the hunter's hut,
the flat-boat, the maize-
leaf
, the flat-boat, the claim, the rude fence,
and the backwood's village,

See, on the one side , the Western sea, the Mississippi and the Missouri,
how they run down through
and on the other side the Eastern
my poems, southerly, central
sea, how they
use and decline sink
advance and retreat
moistening all,
upon my poems,
as upon their
own shores,

See, pastures and forests in my
poems,—See, animals wild and
tame,—See, beyond the Kansas;
herds of buffalo feeding on the
short curly grass.—

Se
a
e
, by the sea-side bathing, free
from costumes, the full-grown
and chaste body of a man,
or the full-grown and chaste
body of a woman,

¶ See, in my poems, old and new cities, solid,
vast, inland, with paved streets, with
iron and stone edific
e
es
, and
ceaseless vehicles, and commerce;

See, the President, ashamed, scouted
at by the people for his de-
relictions,

See, the populace, millions upon
millions, handsome, tall,
muscular, both sexes, clothed
in easy and dignified clothes,
teaching, commanding, marrying,
generating, equally electing and
elective;

See, the many-cylinder'd steam
printing-press—See, the electric
telegraph—See, the strong and quick
locomotive as it
passes
departs, panting,
blowing the
whistle

See, ploughman ploughing the
farms—See, miners
working
digging
the mines—See, the
iron-
numberless
factories,

See, mechanics busy at their
benches with tools—See
from among them
new
superior
judges, philosophs, Presidents,
emerge, dressed in working-
dresses;

See, lounging through the shops
and fields of The States,
me, well-beloved, close-held
by day and night,

Hear the jocund echos of my jocund
songs
of my voice call songs
there—Read the
hints
hints that has
come at last.—

O rendezvous at last! O
us two only!

O power, liberty, eternity at
last! O to be so blithe!

O to be relieved of distinctions!
To make as much of vices
as virtues! To level occupa-
tions and the sexes! To
bring all to common ground!

O adhesiveness! O the pensive
aching to be together—you
know not why and I
know not why;

O a word to clear one's path
ahead endlessly!

O something extatic and unde-
monstrable! O music wild!

O now I triumph—and you
shall also,

O hand in hand—O wholesome
pleasure—O one more desirer
and lover!

O to haste, firm-holding—to haste,
haste on with me.—

I
will
yet
dart forth Religion,

I will
shout
utter
the free canticles of it—
they shall rise and soar into the air,

I see that none have ever yet been devout enough—none had ever yet worshipt
half enough,

None have begun to think how divine
a man
himself
is,
nor
or
how sure the
future is.

I distinctly announce that the greatest part
of America, or of any nation, must
be its Religion.—

Of all that a man needs, I say he needs
nothing any more than he needs Religion,

Always he needs Love—but he does not need
it any more than he needs Religion—per-
haps not as much as he needs Religion,

Perhaps even the best of Love is that where
it is there is the preparation and readiness
for Religion.—

This
The
unseen something in all
things,
life,

Th
is
e
prophetic spririt of materials shifting
and flickering around me,

Th
is
e
wondrous interplay between the divinity
of the future and the divinity of
the present,
